metadata.description: State emergency declaration law defaults for US states with curated DST declarations. Used to calculate auto-expire dates and validate end dates.
metadata.researchNote: Compiled from state statutes. State emergency laws change infrequently (constitutional/statutory level).

TX.notes: Governor may issue for up to 30 days, renewable by proclamation. Legislature can terminate by concurrent resolution.

NC.notes: 30-day initial period. Governor can extend to 60 days. Cannot reissue substantially similar declaration if General Assembly declines to extend.

VA.notes: 45-day hard cap. Governor explicitly prohibited from reissuing same/similar order for same emergency without General Assembly action during original 45 days.

NY.notes: Emergency orders expire after 30 days unless renewed. Post-COVID reform (2021).

PA.citation: Pa. Const. Art. IV, Sec. 20 (2021 amendment); 35 Pa.C.S. § 7301(c)
PA.notes: 21-day limit per 2021 constitutional amendment (voters approved Question 2, May 18, 2021). Supersedes older 90-day statutory limit. Governor cannot reissue for same facts without General Assembly approval.

DE.notes: 30-day default. Renewal requires Governor finding + General Assembly approval.

GA.notes: 30-day default. General Assembly can terminate by concurrent resolution at any time.

NM.notes: 30-day default. Up to 90 days if governor calls special session. Extensions 60 days each, requiring another special session call.

KY.notes: 30-day default per SB1 (2021) amendment. General Assembly approval required for extension. Direct response to COVID-era emergency powers disputes.

LA.notes: 30-day default. Governor can renew. Legislature can terminate by concurrent resolution.

AR.notes: 60-day default. Governor can renew, though legislative oversight mechanisms exist.

MS.notes: 45-day default. No new proclamation for same conditions without Legislature authorization.

IN.notes: 30-day statutory default. Note: Gov. Braun's EO 26-03 stated 60-day duration — may have used broader authority or energy emergency provision (IC 10-14-3-13).

MD.notes: 30-day default. Governor must renew. General Assembly can terminate by joint resolution at any time.

WV.notes: 60-day default. Legislature extends via concurrent resolution. Combined preparedness + emergency max 90 days without extension.

SC.notes: 15-day default. Very short window. General Assembly consent required to extend. Governors issue new EOs in 15-day cycles.

TN.notes: 45-day default (amended from 60). Governor can renew without legislative approval.

CT.notes: Governor specifies enforcement period per order, max 6 months. No automatic renewal mechanism.

OH.notes: 90-day default. Only legislature can extend (60-day increments). After 30 days, legislature can terminate. Governor cannot re-declare similar emergency for 60 days after legislative termination.

KS.notes: 15-day default. Extensions via Legislative Coordinating Council (5 of 6 votes) or full legislature. Max 30 days per extension.

MO.notes: No statutory duration limit. Terminates only by governor proclamation or legislative resolution. Governor sets duration in each EO. No COVID-era reform enacted.

AL.notes: 60-day default. Alabama Emergency Management Act of 1955. Governor or legislature can extend.

NJ.notes: No automatic expiration for disaster emergencies. Remains until governor issues termination. Note: public health emergencies have separate 30-day auto-termination.

ME.notes: 30-day default. Governor may renew. Legislature may terminate by joint resolution.

MA.citation: Ch. 639, Acts of 1950, Sec. 5 (MA Civil Defense Act)
MA.notes: No statutory time limit. Remains until governor determines emergency no longer exists. General Court has no explicit statutory power to terminate unilaterally.

CA.notes: No auto-expiration. Governor 'shall proclaim the termination at the earliest possible date that conditions warrant' (§ 8629). Only two paths: governor proclamation or concurrent resolution of Legislature.

DC.notes: 15-day default. Extension requires Mayor request + DC Council emergency act. Very short window.
